message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The situation suggests child abuse, and a complete skeletal survey is needed to detect other injuries and to report the case to proper authorities. The options for copper levels, collagen testing, and VDRL testing do not have any relevance to the situation presented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fracture in a child with a suspicious mechanism of injury and the green-colored bruise suggest the need for a complete skeletal survey to detect other possible bony injuries and to report the case as suspected child abuse. Checking copper levels might be necessary for Wilson disease, but it is not related to the current case. Collagen biochemical testing is not necessary for this case. Running a VDRL test is not relevant to the case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The femur fracture and green-colored bruise on the left arm suggest possible child abuse. A complete skeletal survey should be obtained to detect other injuries and report the case to the appropriate authorities. Checking copper levels, collagen testing, and running a VDRL test are not indicated in this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The femur fracture and the green bruise on the left arm suggest child abuse, and a complete skeletal survey should be obtained to detect other bony injuries as well as report the case of child abuse. Checking copper levels (option A) and running a VDRL test (option D) are not relevant in this case. Collagen biochemical testing (option B) is not indicated as it is not related to the presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of a femur fracture and a green-colored bruise on the left arm is highly concerning for child abuse. A complete skeletal survey should be obtained to detect any other injuries and to report the case of child abuse to the appropriate authorities. Checking copper levels, collagen biochemical testing, and running a VDRL test are not relevant to this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Given the history and examination findings, there is a high suspicion of child abuse. It is important to obtain a complete skeletal survey to check for other injuries and report any potential child abuse cases. Checking copper levels, collagen biochemical testing, and running a VDRL test are not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a femur fracture in a 3-year-old without any significant mechanism of injury raises concern for non-accidental trauma, and a complete skeletal survey should be obtained to evaluate for other injuries. The other options are not relevant to the current presentation of the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of the femur fracture and the green-colored bruise on the left arm is concerning for physical abuse. A complete skeletal survey should be obtained in order to detect other potential injuries and a report should be made to the appropriate child protection agency. Checking copper levels (A) and running a serum VDRL test (D) are not relevant to the management of a suspected case of child abuse. Collagen biochemical testing (B) may be useful in certain cases of suspected child abuse that involve skeletal fragility disorders, but it is not the next best step in this patient's management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a femur fracture, which is concerning for child abuse. Therefore, the next step in management should be to obtain a complete skeletal survey to detect any other bony injuries and report the case as suspected child abuse. Checking copper levels or running a VDRL test would not be relevant or appropriate in this situation. Collagen biochemical testing is also not necessary for suspected child abuse.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a femur fracture in a child with a questionable history of trauma raises concern for child abuse. A complete skeletal survey is necessary to detect other bony injuries and to report a potential case of child abuse. Copper levels and VDRL tests are not relevant in this case. Collagen biochemical testing is not commonly used in the evaluation of suspected child abuse.
